During research
Safety first!
The main data management task during the research process is to store data safely as they are generated, with regular backups. At this stage, data are generally shared only within a research team. A team may include external partners (other groups/departments from the same institute, other Max Planck institutes and beyond the Max Planck Society).
 
Numerous MPDL tools/services are available to Max Planck researchers and – upon invitation – their external collaborators. Additional (more discipline-specific) ones may exist at individual institutes.
Tooools!
 
 
Storing data solely on a local harddisk, laptop or USB stick is very risky and therefore not recommended. Storage media may deteriorate or could be lost, stolen, damaged or destroyed (e.g. during a fire). You might also delete data accidentally. A good rule of thumb is to store data three times, on two different media, with one copy off-site (3-2-1 rule). Backups should be performed regularly – automatic backups are better than manual ones which you might forget. Also verify that backups are working, and that you have access to these files.
 
See also: Perker, J.M., 2019: 11 ways to avert a data-storage disaster. Nature 568, 
doi: 10.1038/d41586-019-01040-w.
 
Topics covered in the previous section may require ongoing attention: A data management plan needs to be followed, and may have to be updated while research is ongoing. Sensitive personal data obviously require special care throughout the research process.
